ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Various techniques to approximate ODEs and PDEs.

A fundamental knowledge of numerical methods for differential equations, including methods for IVP ODEs, BVP ODEs, and PDEs. We also talked about how to implement such methods, their costs and difficulties, and additional analysis including stability. I feel confident to now utilize numerical methods for research and/or other academic purposes.
I learned how to apply various numerical methods to solve ordinary and partial differential equations and be more efficient when coding to minimize computational cost.

Learn how to apply numerical approximation methods for a variety of types of differential equations. Due to the nature of the homework, you also brush up on good coding practices but little coding experience is expected of you entering the class.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
The class is good! Professor Bennett does a great job with the class. It's super organized, the expectations are clear, and there are plenty of opportunities for extra help, just like all of her classes. Lectures are a bit dry, but this year they were all recorded so you could go back and review a concept you didn't quite grasp in the class.

It's definitely a lot of work though. It's not even like the work is exceptionally difficult and the coding problems can even be somewhat fun to do, but there is just a lot of it. I ended up devoting my Sundays from like 9AM to 9PM exclusively to this class. The Pset we had to do over Spring Break, which ended up being the most difficult code to write, was pretty annoying. 

Overall, I'd still recommend taking this class, but just make sure you balance your courseload appropriately.

Strengths: Professor Bennett was clearly invested in teaching this course. The class was incredibly organized, with a semester-long calendar available, frequent updates from the instructor and TA, detailed and well-thought out lectures, ample office hours, and useful handouts to facilitate engagement with the material. This is truly one of the best taught courses at Yale I have ever taken, and the material is incredibly important for quantitative analysis and research. 

Weaknesses: no real weaknesses. The psets will take at least 10-15 hours, but the work we do each week is incredibly rewarding.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, I would. I definitely enjoyed it overall. But again, know that this class involves a fair amount of work so make sure to balance out your schedule appropriately.

Absolutely! If you are willing to put in the work on the weekly homework, attend all the lectures and ask questions, and get excited about the material, this is a wonderful course that combines fundamental math concepts, computer programming, and result analysis.
Yes, this course is great, and you will learn a lot from it. It is a great course to take if you are going into a field that deals heavily with computation and applied mathematics.
Yes, especially with Professor Bennett. The class is challenging but definitely worth the skills developed and there is as much help for the class as you are willing to seek out.

extras.title: ENAS 441 01/ENAS 748 01/MENG 441 01 - Appl Num Methods for Diff Eqs
